segments.en: Numbered Discourses 8
2. The Great Chapter
13. A Thoroughbred

segments.pli: “Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhaddo assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: “Mendicants, a fine royal thoroughbred with eight factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and considered a factor of kingship.
What eight?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño bhaddo assājānīyo ubhato sujāto hoti—
segments.en: It’s when a fine royal thoroughbred is well born on both
the mother’s and the father’s sides.

segments.pli: Yassaṃ disāyaṃ aññepi bhaddā assājānīyā jāyanti, tassaṃ disāyaṃ jāto hoti.
segments.en: He’s bred in the region fine thoroughbreds come from.
Whatever food he’s given,
fresh or dry,
he eats carefully, without making a mess.

segments.pli: Jegucchī hoti uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā abhinisīdituṃ vā abhinipajjituṃ vā.
segments.en: He’s disgusted by sitting or lying down in excrement or urine.

segments.pli: Sorato hoti sukhasaṃvāso, na ca aññe asse ubbejetā.
segments.en: He’s sweet-natured and pleasant to live with, and he doesn’t upset the other horses.

segments.pli: Yāni kho panassa honti sāṭheyyāni kūṭeyyāni jimheyyāni vaṅkeyyāni, tāni yathābhūtaṃ sārathissa āvikattā hoti.
segments.en: He openly shows his tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints to his trainer,
so the trainer can try to subdue them.
He carries his load, determining:

segments.pli: ‘Kāmaññe assā vahantu vā mā vā, ahamettha vahissāmī’ti cittaṃ uppādeti.
segments.en: ‘Whether or not the other horses carry their loads, I’ll carry mine.’
He always walks in a straight path.

segments.pli: Thāmavā hoti yāva jīvitamaraṇapariyādānā thāmaṃ upadaṃsetā.
segments.en: He’s strong, and stays strong even until death.

segments.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhaddo assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: A fine royal thoroughbred with these eight factors is worthy of a king. …

segments.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti … pe … anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
segments.en: In the same way, a mendicant with eight factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
What eight?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
Whatever food they’re given,
coarse or fine,
they eat carefully, without annoyance.
They're disgusted with bad conduct by way of body, speech, or mind,

segments.pli: jegucchī hoti anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā.
segments.en: and by attainment of the many kinds of unskillful things.

segments.pli: Sorato hoti sukhasaṃvāso, na aññe bhikkhū ubbejetā.
segments.en: They're sweet-natured and pleasant to live with, and they doesn’t upset the other mendicants.

segments.pli: Yāni kho panassa honti sāṭheyyāni kūṭeyyāni jimheyyāni vaṅkeyyāni, tāni yathābhūtaṃ āvikattā hoti satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu.
segments.en: They openly show their tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints to their sensible spiritual companions,

segments.pli: Tesamassa satthā vā viññū vā sabrahmacārī abhinimmadanāya vāyamati.
segments.en: so they can try to subdue them.
They do their training, determining:

segments.pli: ‘Kāmaññe bhikkhū sikkhantu vā mā vā, ahamettha sikkhissāmī’ti cittaṃ uppādeti.
segments.en: ‘Whether or not the other mendicants do their training, I’ll do mine.’
They always walk in a straight path.
And here the straight path is
right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
They’re energetic:

segments.pli: ‘kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upassussatu maṃsalohitaṃ; yaṃ taṃ purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena pattabbaṃ, na taṃ apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Gladly, let my skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the blood and flesh waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by manly strength, energy, and vigor.’

segments.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti … pe … anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
segments.en: A mendicant with these eight factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

sections.title: “Mendicants, a fine royal thoroughbred with eight factors is…

suttaplex.blurb: With eight qualities a royal thoroughbred is worthy of a king. Likewise, with eight qualities a mendicant is worthy.
